The Mayor must submit a performance accountability plan by March 1 each year, outlining measurable performance goals for all government activities in the subsequent fiscal year. The District of Columbia government must provide a performance accountability plan outlining measurable goals for all activities funded by the government, including measures of program outcomes and results. The plan must also identify the management employee responsible for each goal. The performance accountability plan for the District of Columbia government must include measurable goals, program outcomes, and the responsible management employee. Additionally, it should describe activities subject to court orders and their requirements. The Mayor is required to submit a Performance Accountability Report by March 1 of each year to specific committees and the Comptroller General. The Performance Accountability Report for the District of Columbia government must include actual performance levels compared to stated goals, responsible management employees, and the status of court orders. The Performance Accountability Report for the District of Columbia government must include the status of court orders and steps taken to comply. The Comptroller General evaluates each report and submits comments to relevant committees by April 15. Additionally, a Financial Accountability Plan and Report must be developed and submitted by March 1. The Mayor must develop and submit a 5-year financial plan for the District of Columbia government by March 1 each year, outlining steps to balance expenditures and revenues. Additionally, an annual compliance report must be submitted by March 1, starting in 1997. The Mayor submits an annual report to various committees and officials on the District of Columbia's compliance with financial accountability requirements outlined in the 5-year plan. The report is reviewed by the Comptroller General and the Director of the Congressional Budget Office. The reports include a comparison of actual to forecasted cash receipts and disbursements, a projection of remaining months cash forecast for the fiscal year, and explanations for differences between actual and forecasted cash amounts for each month. The quarterly financial reports submitted by the Mayor include comparisons of actual and forecasted cash amounts for each month, explanations for changes in forecasts, impacts on budget compliance, potential need for supplemental budget requests or policy adjustments, aging of receivables and payables, and department-specific data.
